bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861-65.)

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: contusions and wounds of the abdominal parietes
ball entered cartilage opposite external rib and lodged
ball lodged in transverse muscle opposite wound of entrance

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, identified keyword terms
checked OCR; added minimal mark-up for personal names, place names, and dates

body.p: CASE 41.—Private Theodore Lozar, Co. H, 15th New Jersey, shot, at the battle of Chancellorsville, May 3, 1863. A conoidal musket ball entered at the cartilage opposite the left external rib and lodged. The man was conveyed to Washington, and entered Douglas Hospital on May 7th. On May 11th, Assistant Surgeon W. Thomson, U. S. A., discovered the projectile (FIG. 4) in the right transverse muscle, opposite the wound of entrance, and removed it through a counter incision. The patient contracted variola, and was transferred to Kalorama Hospital on June 7, 1863, where he died July 19, 1863, with pyæmic complications.

figure.head: FIG. 4.—Conoidal musket ball removed from abdominal walls. Spec. 4622.
